God bless them and their families. God bless all our veterans. And may God continue to bless the United States of America.

It's our responsibility to ensure that they are never forgotten, that their families are properly cared for, and that we all lead lives worthy of their sacrifice. 

I hope you will join me in remembering our fallen troops today and for all the days yet to come.

These tributes reminded me of the extraordinary sacrifices that all those in uniform make for the rest of us. We owe all those who serve our deepest gratitude and, of course, owe eternal thanks to all those who have made the ultimate sacrifice in defense of this great country.

This was an incredibly moving remembrance of more than 7,000 American heroes, each recognized by the display of an empty boot, including the 29 Rhode Islanders like Captain August who have lost their lives in service to our country.

I also joined Operation Stand Down Rhode Island at Fort Adams State Park in Newport last Friday where volunteers set up the Boots on the Ground for Heroes Memorial to honor all the service members who have died since September 11th.
For sure, future generations of Rhode Islanders will be forever inspired by his courage and service.

A decorated Army Captain, he gave our country more in his 28 years on this earth than most of us will give in our entire lifetimes. The depth of his sacrifice and devotion to our country is difficult to capture in words.
A week ago, I attended the dedication of the Captain Matthew J. August Post Office in Saunderstown. Captain August was killed in January 2004, while serving in Iraq.

In summary:

1. Opening Impeachment Inquiry

2. Investigation and Evidence Gathering

3. Consideration of Articles of Impeachment by Judiciary Committee

4. Consideration of Articles of Impeachment by Full House

5. Trial by Senate

5. Senate Trial

Even once impeached by the House, the President is not removed from office, until such time as he or she is convicted by the Senate on a 2/3 vote of its members.

4. House Floor Vote on Impeachment:

If Articles of Impeachment are filed, the House will be asked to vote on these articles. Passage results in the official charging of the President for having committed high crimes and misdemeanors.

3. Articles of Impeachment:

Once the Judiciary Committee completes its investigation, it may vote for Articles of Impeachment if the evidence supports the finding that the President has committed high crimes and misdemeanors. If not, it will decline to file such charges.

2. Investigation:

Once an inquiry has been opened, evidence is gathered, witnesses are called and documents reviewed.

1. Opening an Impeachment Inquiry:

A formal opening of the process to consider whether the President has committed high crimes and misdemeanors.

But if President Trump succeeds, insurance companies will once again be able to discriminate against individuals with pre-existing conditions, including nearly half of all Rhode Islanders.
Rhode Islanders want access to quality, affordable health care.
It’s time for real action to address this threat and create new, good-paying jobs.

More than 4 out of 5 Rhode Islanders want us to take action. It’s time for the President and his Republican allies to stop doing the bidding of fossil fuel CEOs. Stop denying the science of climate change.

There are already more than 15,000 Rhode Islanders working in clean energy jobs today – that’s up 72 percent from five years ago. Investing in these jobs will expand economic opportunity here in Rhode Island and across America.
Not only will addressing climate change protect the jobs we already have, it will also create new opportunities to build a stronger economy in Rhode Island.

We can’t afford to ignore it – especially in Rhode Island. If climate change continues, it will devastate our fishing and tourism industries, which support nearly 90,000 Rhode Island jobs and more than $7 billion in economic activity for our state each year.
If we don’t act, climate change will have a devastating impact on Rhode Island. No matter what Republicans say, the threat is real and getting worse every day.
